I'm happy to say that at both of the public schools my girls go to, they enjoy the gym classes immensely because the teachers do a great job of making it interesting, fun, and productive. They invent games and competitions (gym Olympics and quidditch in the gym) and encourage the kids. Yet, there have been periods of time when gym was canceled or there wasn't enough time to give all the classes access regularly.
They do at least get recess, in which there's a great deal of running around--often games are organized by assistants. But that kind of activity will fade as the kids get older. And of course in NYC, it fades for most of the school year because of the weather.

At the end of the day, though, if the educational system does not value it, and society is only interested in how productive someone is over the short-term, physical education and health will suffer.

There are many factors that go into making a healthy society, but basic physical exercise at these minimal levels is really a must. And these really are minimal levels.

I'm not sure who you think is moving out of NJ, but I'm not sure why a multi-millionaire would leave. I'm also not sure why most of NJ isn't up-in-arms about the 9% tax break multimillionaires get on their property taxes.

This story says a lot about the hyprocisy of the Republican party.

Republican members of the Miami-Dade School Board in Florida -- a heavily contested battleground state this November -- sent a message to First Lady Michelle Obama Tuesday: Stay out of our school.

According to the Miami Herald, two GOP board members urged that a campaign event at Barbara Goleman Senior High in Miami Lakes be cancelled and questioned its legality.

“Allowing the first lady of the United States to use one of our schools explicitly to benefit the president’s reelection campaign is inappropriate and sends the wrong message to our students, employees, and to taxpayers – even if the president’s campaign is willing to pay for all costs resulting from the event,” board member Carlos Curbelo wrote in the letter to the board's attorney.

Said fellow board member Renier Diaz de la Portilla: “The use of public schools whose only focus should be to educate our children for political gain is downright wrong. Don’t these liberals have boundaries? Our schools are places for learning, not places for politicking.”

The complaint came as Republican Mitt Romney was set to hold a campaign event at a public high school in Colorado where President Obama held a town hall meeting three years ago.

Miami-Dade school board attorney Walter Harvey said the district's policy allows all groups, including political ones, to lease facilities. He said the Obama campaign was paying $2,351 to rent the school for the event.
Good luck with that, Mitt...

Many of those responding here got it right. The problem is not the level of taxation in Kansas. It is the fact that economically and culturally, Kansas has become an empty shell. There are states with much higher levels of taxation (Calif., N.Y., Hawaii and Mass., among many others) that attract millions of Americans because of their high quality of life and greater levels of economic opportunity. Kansas has become an economically depressed state full of towns from which young adults flee because they don't want to spend their lives in minimum-wage jobs. I should know: I'm one of them. When I fled Kansas at the age of 25, I instantly more than doubled my income and gained a health plan. The Wal-Martized Kansas economy does attract new residents, but they tend to speak Spanish, and for the most part, they are regarded as liabilities rather than assets. It's all very sad.

Thanks dred. I didn't realize that lowering taxes was like a sale at a store! I suppose, like a sale, I'm getting a better deal when I drive down each road or when the police stop a drunk driver. I know that each time my taxes go down I immediately go out and drive around the Beltway here in DC because it is now cheaper for me to do so. I also give my local police and fire departments a call and ask them to come by because it now costs me less!

Lowering taxes is NOTHING like a sale. First, what product would the government be selling? And, why would more people purchase more of it? Every "product" of the government that I know of - roads, fire, police, education, health, military, etc. - are all fixed costs, i.e. things that must be paid for in this day and age. In other words, having a "sale" on government "products" either means simply losing money - since we were going to buy those things anyway - or not having a store. Second, if lower taxes ALWAYS meant increased revenue, then a tax rate of 0% means infinite revenue! Oh wait, zero times anything is still zero. If you think Maryland is proving anything with it's millionaire's tax, you should consider the situation had they not changed the rate: EVEN LESS MONEY. It may not generate the income it's "supposed to" but, in the end, the point was simply to generate income! Just because someone made a bad prediction doesn't mean the tax isn't working.

Concerned Reader, you do know that the 20% number you are quoting includes ALL tax rates. It is a number that gets thrown around a lot by Republicans who argue that regardless of the tax structure the government will never be able to collect more than about 20% of GDP in taxes. Maybe they're right, but you're definitely wrong to advance the argument that the 20% you are quoting refers to the same thing as the 70% and 50% above. The 50% and 70% would be a part of the 20%, if anything.

False choice "G Boston"?

"The answer is to cut taxes AND keep choices"?

My, that rolls right off the tongue?

But what does it mean?

In the "real world"--or at least the world I live in--good schools, good roads and infrastructure, and good public services--you know, the police, the firefighters, the EMTs--all cost money.

I spent seven years living in one of those so-called "low tax" states--Oklahoma, to be precise.

Gas taxes--which most states use to pay for their roads and highways--were the lowest in the nation. And the lunar rover would be a good choice for driving in that state.

Property taxes--which most states use to pay for schools--were also low. And the schools resembled something just this side of the stone age.

My "choices" on education in the state thanks to those low taxes?

Most of the rich people in the state chose to send their children to private schools where the annual tuition per child was north of $15,000.

Some choice.

Funny thing "G"--when my tax accountant added everything up--what I saved on income and property tax--versus what I forked over in the form of a sales tax that applied to EVERYTHING--and a license plate fee that was over $900 a year (compared with $35 in New York) he ran the numbers and concluded that my effective tax rate was actually higher than what I had been paying in New York.

Sorry G--but in the real world--there's no such thing as a free lunch.

Asserting they do is specious nonsense--as bogus as your assertion that "Lowering taxes ALWAYS increases revenue."
